articles.headline: Carving a Legacy of Giving (to His Party, Too)
articles.snippet: On a recent trip to Africa, Bill Clinton showed how he is bringing his family deeper into the Clinton Foundation, perhaps confronting a future without him.
articles.abstract: On a recent trip to Africa, Bill Clinton showed how he is bringing his family deeper into the Clinton Foundation, perhaps confronting a future without him.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAYONZA, Rwanda — Bill Clinton could not stop talking about soybeans. Over dinner in Kigali with a handful of longtime political aides and deep-pocketed donors, he recited the price of soy (“It never exceeded $8, and now it’s $16”) and extolled its virtues as a miracle crop (“You can grow it with just a thin layer of topsoil”).

articles.headline: G.O.P. Shift Moves Center Far to Right
articles.snippet: A look back at Richard Nixon’s stands on big government programs and new regulations underscores how much the political center has moved.
articles.abstract: A look back at Richard Nixon’s stands on big government programs and new regulations underscores how much the political center has moved.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear Republicans on the campaign trail, the United States could not have elected a more left-wing president than Barack Obama, one more hostile to business or more eager to expand government power. Left-wing Democrats, I’m sure, would disagree. If they had their druthers, they would probably make a more liberal, more pro-big government choice. Somebody, perhaps, like Richard Nixon.

articles.headline: A Chinese City Moves to Limit New Cars
articles.snippet: Guangzhou wants to improve quality of life through license plate auctions and lotteries expected to halve the number of new cars on the streets.
articles.abstract: Guangzhou wants to improve quality of life through license plate auctions and lotteries expected to halve the number of new cars on the streets.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — It is as startling as if Detroit or Los Angeles restricted car ownership.

articles.headline: Iran Supplying Syrian Military via Iraqi Airspace
articles.snippet: Iran has resumed shipping military equipment to Syria over Iraqi airspace, showing the limits of American influence in the region after the White House pressed Baghdad to close the corridor.
articles.abstract: Iran has resumed shipping military equipment to Syria over Iraqi airspace, showing the limits of American influence in the region after the White House pressed Baghdad to close the corridor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has resumed shipping military equipment to Syria over Iraqi airspace in a new effort to bolster the embattled government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, according to senior American officials.

articles.headline: Facebook Moves to Aid Its Shares
articles.snippet: The chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, aimed to instill confidence in Wall Street by saying he would hold on to his shares and options longer and allow his employees to start selling their shares sooner.
articles.abstract: The chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, aimed to instill confidence in Wall Street by saying he would hold on to his shares and options longer and allow his employees to start selling their shares sooner.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — “Stay focused and keep shipping” may be the motto Facebook has sought to follow since its flubbed public offering three months ago. But on Tuesday, the company seemed focused mostly on how to stabilize its hemorrhaging stock.

articles.headline: Banks Face Suits as States Weigh Libor Losses
articles.snippet: The scandal over global interest rates has states working to build a case for suing the nation’s largest banks.
articles.abstract: The scandal over global interest rates has states working to build a case for suing the nation’s largest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scandal over global interest rates has state officials like Janet Cowell of North Carolina working intensely behind the scenes to build a case for suing the nation’s largest banks.

articles.headline: Michelle Obama Tops Opening Night for Democrats
articles.snippet: Democrats had two simple messages for voters: Mitt Romney does not get it, and President Obama does. The main attraction was Mr. Obama’s lead character witness: his wife, Michelle.
articles.abstract: Democrats had two simple messages for voters: Mitt Romney does not get it, and President Obama does. The main attraction was Mr. Obama’s lead character witness: his wife, Michelle.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Democrats opened their convention here on Tuesday night with a parade of officials telling voters that Mitt Romney does not get it and with a rousing speech from Michelle Obama making the case that President Obama does.
